'''Alice Leslie Carter''' was an [[United States|American]] [[classic female blues]] singer. She was active as a recording artist in the early 1920s, and her best known tracks were "Decatur Street Blues" and "Aunt Hagar's Children Blues".<ref name="AMG">{{cite web |first= |last= |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p340345/biography|pure_url=yes}} |title=Biography by Eugene Chadbourne |publisher=Allmusic.com |accessdate=October 4, 2011}}</ref> Although Carter was a contemporary of better known recording artists of the time, such as [[Ma Rainey]], [[Bessie Smith]], [[Clara Smith]],  [[Victoria Spivey]], [[Sippie Wallace]], and [[Bertha "Chippie" Hill]], little is known of her life outside of her music.

She is not to be confused with Alice Carter, another [[blues]] singer, who recorded four songs in 1923.<ref name="AMG"/><ref>{{cite book
| first= Allan
| last= Sutton
| year= 2005
| title= Pseudonyms on American records, 1892-1942
| edition= 2nd
| publisher= Mainspring Press
| location= Michigan
| isbn= 0-9671819-9-2
| page= 38}}</ref>

==Career==
Carter recorded eleven sides in 1921, with musical accompaniment led by [[James P. Johnson]] on piano.  She recorded at a time when [[record label]]s were keen to sign up anyone capable of singing a blues song, such was the market demand.  However, while some of these performers were less than capable, Carter's work showed her strong vocal abilities.<ref name="AMG"/> Her output included the first vocalised recording of the [[W. C. Handy]] and [[James Tim Brymn|Tim Brymn]] co-written song, "Aunt Hagar's Children Blues."<ref name="Album"/><ref>{{cite book
| first= John Edgar
| last= Tidwell
| year= 2007
| title= Montage of a dream: the art and life of Langston Hughes
| edition= 1st
| publisher= University of Missouri Press
| location= Columbia, Missouri
| isbn= 978-0-8262-1716-5
| page= 27}}</ref>

On January 20, 1922, Carter competed against [[Lucille Hegamin]], [[Daisy Martin]], and the eventual winner [[Trixie Smith]], in a blues singing contest at the Inter-Manhattan Casino in [[New York City]].<ref>{{cite book
| first= Paul
| last= Oliver
| year= 1997
| title= The Story of the Blues
| edition= 2nd
| publisher= Northeastern University Press
| location= Boston, Massachusetts
| isbn= 1-55553-355-8
| page= 77}}</ref>  In the printed programme she was billed as "The International Blues Star", from which [[David Evans (musicologist)|David Evans]] infers that she may have toured in Europe with an American band after [[World War I]].<ref>Evans, David (1996). notes to ''Female  Blues Singers Volume 4:C''. Document DOCD-5508.</ref>

All of her recorded output was included on the [[compilation album]], ''Female Blues Singers, Vol. 4: C (1921-1930)'', released in 1997 by [[Document Records]].<ref name="Album">{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=album|id=r259119/review|pure_url=yes}} |title=Allmusic ((( ''Female Blues Singers, Vol. 4: C (1921-1930)'' > Review )))}}</ref>
